1839
XY Note of Mr. Ivory relating to the correcting 
of an error in a Paper printed in the Phil. 
Tranns for 1838, pp. 57 &c.
In the paper referred to, Phil. Tranns. 1838 
p. 63, it is said “Let V stand for the 
integral in the equation (7), and supposing 
that p and T[squared] vary so as always to satisfy that 
equation, we shall have 
dV/[delta]p.dp + ddV/TdT = 0.” 
Now the error alluded to consists in having 
given a wrong sign to the differential dV/TdT, 
the value of which, as has been said, is 
modified, in the question under conside:
ration, by the equation (7). This mistake 
vitiates the concluding part of the Paper, in 
app. 63, 64, 65, as far as relates to the li:
mits of <s>variables<\s> the quantities p and T[squared]. M. Lionsville 
has done the author of the Paper the honour 
of noticing and correcting the mistake in his <u>Journal
de Math.ques for April 1839<\u>. When the sign of 
the differential is rightly ascertained, 
the analysis pursued in the Paper leads 
to a simple determination of the limits 
sought, as this Note will prove, the pro:
priety of printing which in the Phil. Transns. 
is submitted to the Council.
